The GPWS CPU (Central Processing Unit) is able to detect:
1) excessive descent rate.
2) rapidly rising terrain.
3) excessive angle of attack.
4) excessive pitch down attitude.
5) loss of altitude during go-around.
6) abnormal flaps configuration.
7) excessive bank angle.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

2. the climb rate
3. the aircraft configuration
4. the selected engine rpm

options.text: "TOO LOW GEAR", "TOO LOW FLAPS", "TOO LOW TERRAIN"

variant.question:
A transport airplane is compelled to carry on board a Ground Proximity Warning System  (GPWS). This system will warn the crew in case of :
 
1. Keeping the altitude at a lower level than the one shown in the flight plan entered in the FMS.
2. Dangerous ground proximity.
3. Loss of altitude during take-off or missed approach.
4. Wrong landing configuration.
5. Descent below Glide Path, within limits.
 
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is :

The aural alert(s) associated with the mode 3 (altitude loss after take-off or go-around) of the GPWS is (are):
1) "DON'T SINK"
2) "SINKRATE"
3) "TERRAIN"
4) "PULL UP"
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
During an approach you hear the voice alert 'Minimums'. What GPWS mode is that?
The GPWS (Ground Proximity Warning System) is active for a height range from:

options.text: 50 ft to 2 500 ft measured by the radio altimeter
0 ft to 5 000 ft measured by the radio altimeter.
0 ft to 2 500 ft measured by the radio altimeter.
50 ft to 5 000 ft measured by the radio altimeter.

variant.question: The EGPWS provides a forward looking terrain avoidance (FLTA) function; this function uses:

options.text: An electronic map of the world giving ground elevation.
The same caution and warning envelopes as the mode 2 GPWS (excessive terrain closure rate).
The weather radar to detect any high ground in conflict with the flight path of the aircraft.
A specific radar to detect any high ground in conflict with the flight path of the aircraft.

A visual alarm to which a sound alarm can be added.
A sound alarm or a visual alarm.

The purpose of GPWS is...

options.text: to provide information and alert the pilots of a potentially hazardous terrain situation.
to alert the crew if there are deviations from certain aerodynamic parameters like altitude, airspeed and angle of attack.
to avoid the aircraft having a CFIT.
to alert the pilots of hazardous terrain in front of and below the aircraft.
